headline: Lead Fulfillment Center - Flipkart
pros:
1. Learning Curve.- FK always engage employee with new course and assessment test.
2. Personal growth - FK provide the window to showcase excellence in performance and knowledge, and on these basis one can climb up in management level.
3. Overall knowledge of SCM - Being in FC leading team, enjoyed the supervision of all the Fulfillment center functions which provide a enlarge vison to see the total SCM operation.
4. Interdepartmental Coordination - FK always ensure the attitude of the employee should not think there assets or department work in silo. Regular and periodic meeting conducted and monitored to initiate and drive new project, process implementation and betterment of SCM as a whole.
cons:
1. Work-Life balance - As the work pressure on every individual is high due as the internal data management has lot of discrepancy.
2. Criticality of the process - FK internal software are not integrated so the repetitive escalation happened for unnecessary reason.
3. Personal leaves - As per the policy the annual and casual leaves are provided but senior manager didn't allow the downline team to avail most of it. Many personal befits got violated.

headline: Do not join the supply chain operations team
pros: Good learning opportunity in a ecommerce supply chain, good HR policies and a good brand to work for.
cons: Poor managers/leaders, tendency to find scapegoats whenever things go south, people do not want to take additional responsibilities/ownership of their work. Poor planning and execution coordination, use of foul languages during meeting by asset leaders like Shalabh and zonal managers. Most of the show is driven by central teams. Zonal teams just follow lead and not much bandwidth is there to drive zone specific projects. Every leader has a big inflated ego and don't talk informally with each other. No coordination between assets and most of the times decisions are taken in a siloed manner leading to all kind of challenges. Given all these, role change is very frequent. People only survive in an asset of 1-2 years and they change role as soon as possible after eligibility because there is only so much that one can endure.

headline: Too much focus on Perception Management
pros:
1. Employee policies (like health insurance, leaves policy) etc is good.
2. Job security (mostly)
3. There are good trainings and central learning initiatives taken by org.
4. You have the option to change teams/roles after spending 1 year in the current role/team
cons:
1. Your growth will greatly depend on how good you are at managing your perception rather than your true accomplishments at work. 
If you are an introvert, trust me its going to be extra hard for you. You will be required to create and receive way too much stimulus which is not at all required for your job. You spend 3-4 hours doing something .. another 2 hours drafting impressive mails around it.. another 30 minutes ensuring all important stakeholders, seniors are marked in CC... and then another few hours anxiously checking your inbox who appreciated and who didn't.

2. Not much scope for on job learning unless you are a fresher. Root cause are not discussed openly. The idea is to execute and execute at the speed of light but who is thinking?? A lot of new initiative are not well thought and designed. Relevant stakeholders are not involved in the strategy process. Ultimately , after wasting so many manhours a lot of initiatives are dropped.

3. Since the projects / initiatives are not well thought, problems keep arising and you are always fire fighting. Working hours increase along with pressure to deliver. Very good chances that around BBD you will discover how fast you have aged. On a lighter note, you will loose hair at a very rapid pace .

cons: Very slow in catching up to the market standards in compensation. Poor pay when compared with other startups and MNCs and FAANGs. headline: Really bad place, specially for data science
pros: 3 years back, it was the salary, but that's not true anymore. Other players in the market are offering better salaries.
cons: The work culture has gone from bad to totally insufferable. They have lowered their leadership hiring bar so low, they mostly hire scumbags. My last manager almost used to threaten me with bad ratings to get the work done. For data science, it's possibly the worst. There's no synchronisation between engineering, product and data science. Data scientists are in the end blamed for the failure at the part of DS leadership. Those guys keep getting promoted, and junior folks suffer. Plus they don't have qualified principal data scientists anymore. Most of them are just there to relax and have no vision or skills. Not sure how they got the hype running in the country. It's absolutely worse place. Too much politics, very less focus on actual work. Wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

headline: Head heavy org., with no clear long term vision. The managers are not leaders but simply promotion seeking folks
pros:
- Great peer learning, specially during interaction 
- If you are doing good, you have opportunities to move to different roles/functions within the org
- New interesting customer solutions getting frequently launched give you great experience in terms of leveraging the platform to its full capacity 
- The employee benefits are good and the office facility is also good. You would enjoy working in their ETV campus
cons:
- Manager creates barrier b/w his subordinates and his manager, acting as single point of contact. In my case this gentleman took all the credit of the team's individual contribututiona and took promotion to AD level
- During hiring process the HR post verbal confirmation of the package, went into hiding for a week and then renegotiated the package discussion, clearly showcasing very low talent for HR profiles.
- The seller sentiment towards flipkart is one of the lowest in the market, unfortunately this is irrelevant to the manager and the senior management.

headline: Very bad onboarding + experience + review from old employees
pros:
Based on a team comprising of many other sub teams totalling up to a headcount of ~100 people

1. Decent pay
2. Flexibility (On paper)
cons:
1. Managers are biased to former employees.
2. Wrong description and overselling by hiring manager during hiring.
3. No proper plan to onboard new folks.
4. A lot of maintenance work and very less 'new feature development'
5. 'New feature development' mostly means copying code from one flow and pasting in another flow.
6. People who should be architects are managers and they have no people management skills.
7. It's a big company wants to work in agile environment but want the work to be completed on time like a startup.
8. Flexibility to work on paper, but I have been working 14 hours a day just to onboard.
9. Narcissistic bosses
10. People are randomly shuffled to new teams for some time to expedite project timelines , sometimes putting them in grim situation based on the culture and quality of project planning in that team and this when a person joined 2 weeks back.

headline: Great company, great team, pathetic management
pros:
- Excellent learning opportunity
- World class work environment
- Excellent office 
- Excellent perks
- Talented workforce
cons:
What I am about to write is my observation from my capacity while employed at Flipkart.

The manager I was reporting to had an history for being an unfriendly one. In fact, an entire team had quit because he treated them like a floor mop after an year of slogging to build Flipkart's first datacenter. Of course, this person has his good books and all the employees with 7+ years of experience in that team are people in that book. I would avoid Flipkart if I had to work with this detestable person again.

HR works hand in hand with the management. You are just a pawn on the chess board (unless you are in the good book). Don't expect any justice from these folks. Again, I haven't seen an HR that tries to either. I have only heard of them.

3. Steep learning curve
cons:
1. Bureaucratic - over time, Flipkart has become a giant organisation with office politics and bureaucracy. Lot of time goes into fulfilling the desires and whims of bosses.

headline: Good work culture, decent work, reasonable comp, poor growth, good place to chill
pros:
Good work culture

Flexible timings

Average age of SDEs is in mid 20s

Pretty frequent outings and fun during work is promoted

Pretty ideal for freshers, even more so if you plan for masters/MBA after 2-3 years
cons:
Below average opportunities to grow

Apart from basic pay, comp is pretty abysmal

Compared to its competitor Amazon which gives a minimum of around 10-15L in RSUs, Flipkart's ESOPs absolutely, unequivocally PALE in comparison.

Promotions and levelling up criteria are extremely poorly defined, good engineers can be stuck at the same level for 3-4 years easily

Raises are abysmal unless if you started with a below average comp, in which case higher raises are given to normalize pay across team

Codebase, infra, architecture is poor, although efforts to improve that are being made, its simply not on par with other tech companies in the industry

Growth, learning, guidance and even direction is mostly dependent on self, management is there to ensure good mood of SWEs whenever possible and to deliver product teams demands.

Prone to heavy brain drain, as capable engineers, leave within a few years to FAANG as they give better comp, perks, work and onsite opportunities.

headline: A Startup Driven Culture Turning into Robotic Mass Production Factory
pros: Its a pro success environment for people who want to work 24x7. People who are competent to build their whole life around office(friends, spouse, school).
cons:
Flipkart used to be  startup driven culture where people were trusted with their work. Work timings were flexible and micromanagement was a word not found. Post acquisition, now its going through a complete culture shift where the focus is over making profits at any cost. Prolonged works hours without any remuneration, with weekends turned into BAU  is a regular phenomena. Hirings are now targeted to befrom organizations where  employees have excelled in micromanaging people. Work life balance is a subject of joke inside workspace. People moving up the ladders are the ones who are good in bootlicking and do everything possible to appease managers.

***People who do not have/wish/require a life outside work must join ***

headline: If you want to build a career in Operations, look elsewhere.
pros:
- Nice office
- Sort-of flexible working hours (not always because you'll be working on weekends)
- Timely salary/benefits
cons:
- No training or development for operations managers/leaders
- Operations is treated like a lower caste with business finance and demand treated as kings. Operations literally has to beg to business finance to even get a 10-15k approval.
- People who joined the company circa 2014 saw tremendous growth and now are sitting at leadership positions. Unfortunately hiring back then wasn't as high quality and thus the company is filled with incompetent leaders who lack basic professionalism of any kind. Flipkart (at least Ekart) has turned into a Lala company.
- Lack of quality of work. You don't really get to use your grey cells much. Imagine doing all your analytics work on Google spreadsheets!
- It's more fighting every day than adding value. After a year you'll lose all hopes of making any changes or adding any value.
- Salary is lowest in the industry
- Horrible relationships with external vendors
- You pretty much work 24/7
- The veterans rule the company; if you're a newbie you'll struggle a lot (on a daily basis) - prepare to be discriminated. People with 2-3 years are also struggling btw!

headline: Review after 4 years of full time job at mid-senior level
pros:
* freedom to experiment (provided you are making sense).
* people from different background are working together, which gives you multiple view points around same problem.
* receptive >>> people and mgmt is very receptive towards new ideas.
* Agile >>> very determined towards responding as fast as they can towards business and market.
* Work Environment >>> Best in industry, result driven but not hectic 
* Best HR policies in the industry.
* openness toward letting people moving from one team to another, without any hassle, based on employee preferences and choices.
* best reward system in industry.
cons:
* frequent changing business priorities. 
* frequent change in leadership. 
* performance review has a special soft corner for stakeholder feedback. sometimes performance becomes stakeholder sensitive rather than team/result sensitive. 
* well thought standardization of policies and procedure need to be in place ASAP. (may not be 100% but yes upto 80% extent at-least so that absence of SOP do not become the reason for "passing the bug".

headline: Engineering
pros: When you get hired they may send you a packet of seeds by  courier. Tech stack is the latest, at least so far as the UI teams are concerned. Emphasis on tech rigor. Fruits in the pantry replenished twice a day. Pay for tech roles is competitive. You will work alongside smart people who like their jobs and are enthusiastic about their work and you may find a lot to learn from these people and their code.
cons: Seeds have been sown but they have not grown yet, one can't help but hope that they were not of sub-standard quality. Competitive work culture; intricate peer performance review  process. Sometimes you might find yourself wondering what the meaning of it all is, life universe and everything, and mindless consumerism might then seem like a neat idea in the grand scheme of things. Not sure if politics and attrition here is more or less than national average, but they are not unheard of here. Sometimes there tends to be extra work pressure.

headline: Director of Engineering
pros:
Above avg compensation, good relocation policy
They have 3rd party that can relocate you from anywhere in the world, comparable to other US companies such as AMZN, MSFT, GOOF,  UBER etc
Good stock options if you can ast here to avail them
Flexible timing
Easy Going
cons:
Highly disorganised
Even the HR don't know the policies here
Executives are never available to set direction or even do 1-1
People who have been here for 5+ years have rotten, have sub standard tech skills and lack leadership at all levels. Interacted with EM, SEM, DOE, VP all lack tech skills and more so have least knowldge of management or leadership.
It didn't help that there was too much confusion due to Walmart merger
All hiring plans are put on hold, however the roadmap still remains the same
Promotion policy is very biased and old boys gang wants to promote only their boot lickers
The VPs are never available, nor can solve any problems be it team dynamics, product prioritzation, conflict resolution etc
Legacy infrastructure, majority of the people have no idea about AWS, Azure or any leading public clouds, they continue to use their own data center which doesn't support IaaS, PaaS and let alone any SaaS.
Extremely inefficient middle and top managemnet from EM through VP.
Multiple teams try to do the same thing for instance Data Science is done by labs in US, the data team in India and then another data science team. All 3 teams are lead by 3 different VPs and there is no concensus between each other. Even with so much investment in data sciences you hardly have any usable services or models for ML deployed in prod. They are nt even close to Azure ML, AWS ML, Tensorflow etc.
Highly political, its probably the only company where you will find zero documentation of any of the systems. Architects here will just talk and not code or even publish system design. HLD, LLD etc. 
Only SDE1/2 or perhaps SDE3/4 are the ones who slog and majority of SDE5, PA just blabber and do not deliver any tech roadmaps or architectures.
This organization is filled with deadwood with iept line mangement, and unproductive middle managemnet and unworthy sr management.

headline: Not as good as they project to the world.
pros:
Working at scale so you get a lot of exposure into distributed Micro Services architecture. 

Generally a young company so people are energetic. 

Some good technical people are there and working with them is fun. (fun - a lot of learning, conversation and questions, no pressure even while delivering.)
cons:
Managers put a lot a pressure in the name of "ownership".  This creates unnecessary pressure and stress which affects personal lives.

A lot of how you are treated depends on your designation.

Generally a young company, so most of the people without any real responsibilities otherwise, hence give very long hours to office work. Difficult for experienced people to cope up, unless you directly get into a senior role.

Managers and most other people are interested in getting things done as per the current requirement.Hence, solutions and design are non futuristic and not platform oriented.

headline: E-commerce experience is always  unique and the knowledge is very different diversified.
pros:
You work for your own people, I.e. Indian people starting from the owner of the company to the sellers from different regions of India and the end consumer and those are our own Indian customers.

Amazing  work culture. Here in market place we get trained and we train our sellers/vendors on how to do a better business in ethical grounds and sustain in a long term competitive business and ensure that the sales are always there every month.

Always a Day shift as the sellers of India are only active in the morning and they shut their business usually by 7p.m and starts in the morning by 9.am. 

Leaves are always an added advantage as our client specific holidays are too more in compared to an MNC.

Flipkart serves employees  Unlimited Milk, Machine made Tea and Coffee, Bread, Amul Butter, Jam, Bournvita, Horlicks, Soft Drinks free of cost to the employees inside the pantry next to the bay.

Every month best performers are shared Flipkart and Myntra coupons worth thousands. Also to add Flat 20 percent on any items on Flipkart and Myntra all year round with the unique employee discount code.

Yearly party s or bash are thrown in any of the good resorts in Bangalore. They actually spend a lot on parties.
cons:
No international exposure.
300 employees got sold to different other firms without any prior intimation. I was among those unlucky 300.

headline: Great work-life balance; Good benefits; unenterprising work; sporadic priorities in the higher management
pros:
Work-life balance is great - in the support functions and higher management -
 miserable in the supply chain operations. Monetary benefits are great, again, in the support functions and higher management only. People are friendly, mostly, and biased for action - just because thinking before leaping  is not a general policy here <sigh>. Ecommerce is beckoning with brazen opportunities for innovation - which is another major attraction - limited only by the outlook and foresight of the higher management.
cons: Red-tapism is rearing. Leadership seems capricious - which could be attributed to the nomadic priorities in the top management. HR is occupied to the brim with the affairs of off-rolls. Benefits other than remuneration like learning and training are unheard of.

headline: Terrible place to work at
pros: Open minded people and culture, flexible timings.
cons:
I joined this place as a wide eyed fresher. What I got in return is a lifelong skepticism for overgrown start-ups and corporates. They have hired indiscriminately. There are more people than there are things to do. I literally warmed my seat and not much else during the amount of time I spent there. It was an absolute waste of time and I learnt nothing. Considering I was a fresher I was really excited to learn and grow in my career. 
Another issue that Flipkart is riddled with, is their slowness. Slow is not what I expected from India's first unicorn. Nothing ever gets done, their customer service has degraded as well. 
My sincere advice especially if you are a fresher, do not join this place.

headline: Stay Away From This Place!!!!
pros: Good work life balance as you don't have anything to do. Free snacks.
cons:
I am here for almost a year now. My only learning so far, I have learned to speak like a politician rather than like a techie. 
This place has lost its charm.A place full of politics where people shout more and try to pull you down  rather than proving their worth by working with you. Hardly any good work to do. Managers will promise you about all sort of super awesome work before joining. Once you are trapped and you are in the system you will start appreciating your previous company and regret joining Flipkart everyday. 
People at higher level are only concerned about old folks who are in the system for more than 2 or 3 years. They don't give a damn to new joinees and most of the time you will be without any work or will do some left over work of least priority. All good part of the work will be done by old folks. They are the most insecure species of this planet. They will never discuss about the product/module so that they don't loose their creditability

headline: A great learning experience!
pros:
Joined FK in late Dec 2011. Pretty much a start-up environ then. Underwent an exhaustive training with various verticals of SCM, gained hands on experience working with leaders across Business Development - Vendor Management, Retail procurement, Central Payments, Warehousing, Logistics, Order Management, Risk Operations and Customer Support - All just within 3 years. Witnessed streamlining of processes, induction of new visionary leaders, automation of activities and business analytics that led to a greater control and visibility across SCM.

A fully chillax environ, but on some occasions had to extend over night. I derived encouragement watching my senior folks, couple of whom instilled the feeling of ownership and commitment towards work. Culture was great - never hesitated to meet up Business heads. Processes, KPIs, policies were very dynamic and so were the challenges. An experience of this sort has catapulted several employees to higher positions else where and still continues to do so.
cons: Mid management - Their words and actions sometimes would not be in sync at all. Can't blame them - since they feel the heat both from executives and the management.

headline: Biased towards certain employees
pros:
1. culture - Open, I mean no "sirs", you can call by first name. Management is approachable
2. work - great work, there are many things to work upon hence the day goes just like that. 
3. pressure - lot of work, hence huge pressure. Prioritisation is required a lot of times. 
4. Constantly changing managers - You get to work with new manager almost every six months. High probability that he might be rude, indifferent, uncultured. Most of them are premium B-School pass outs  who hardly care about customers and focus on numbers. 
5. Thought provoking - You are working with a lot of intelligent people around hence you should not accept status quo
cons:
1. Non-objective review - The reviews are objective on paper but subjective in reality. There is a cartel formation going on in some teams. I have seen people going places just because they knew the "right people" or were from a premium b school. 
2. Referrals - Since employee gets a referral bonus, people are more keen towards getting talent from outside than to nurture talent from inside. The referral bonus is huge when you consider Sr. Manager or Manager level. A relative is also considered a referral :-) 
3. Everything happens from Bangalore - If you are working in Delhi, then it will be difficult to show your work. 
4. No accountability - You can roam scot free even after messing up big time, for all you know, you might get promoted too.

headline: Its ok
pros:
1. Good salary. 
2. Flexible work options.
3. Enthusiastic people 
4. Macbooks
5. Good enough tech stack
cons:
1. Too many fresh grads. Agreed that they are really talented and all, but I don't see any logic in promoting people from SDE1 to SDE2 in 6 months! If that goes like this, he will be an architect with 3 years of exp! What next ?
2. Code base has zero documentation. Nobody follows the rule of 20-30% comments in code. Not a single line of comment you will find. Either you infer what the code is doing by reading it, or debug it.
3. Lack of coordination across teams. Teams change their API responses without any notification leading to runtime errors somewhere else! People do not respond to emails and you have to walk to their desks and ask questions.
4. Lots of noise at workplace. No desk phones. At any given point of time you will find at least half of employees not at their desks and discussing stuff at someone else's place. (because many people do not respond on mails, and there is ZERO documentation)
5. Mentorship ? Whats that ?
6. Useless meetings

headline: Screwed up immature hiring process; Immense scope for negotiation during hiring
pros: above market salary to trap you into a bad environment
cons:
Reporting to an immature & inexperienced monkey is the worst danger at flipkart

If you are joining the company, 
(1) Find out the names of all the folks that interviewed you and look up their Linkedin profiles - one of them will be your hiring manager. Ask yourself if you really want to report to the guy
(2) Reject the first offer letter saying designation is not correct. They will get back in a couple of weeks with a revised designation. Extremely unprofessional trying to under-level you
(3) Ask for the organizational structure and find out who are your peers (if they are a decade less experienced than you they are probably immature and you will have issues) and also how long they have been in the grade

Net-net: if you have 10+ years of experience and have worked in professional companies, Flipkart is an 'avoid'. There are better companies out there. This is not a MNC but a 'lalla' indian company

headline: Demanding, fast moving and rewarding
pros:
Has the best opportunities in this industry in India today. Culture of strong ownership is very high, and is usually rewarded very well. Strong performers usually grow very fast.

Has some very talented people in the technology space. Tries to apply technology to a very diverse set of domains.

Is growing very fast and on a very sustainable track. I see the numbers, so I know.

Intent to get better is very strong in key people in the leadership.

Strong breeding ground if you are a quick learner. If you are not, Flipkart might not be the best place.
cons:
The pros listed above are not very uniform across the organisation. Differences between the best and the worst pockets can be shockingly large.

The environment can be too demanding at times, and due to the high focus on ownership, work life balance is not as often spoken about as it should be.

Some policies can feel startup-ish while some feel large company-ish. There is some work that seems to be getting done here, but there is some way to go.
